title: Motor Vehicle Sales: Signs of Supply Side Disruptions?
description: Let's parse the latest data on motor vehicle sales
contents:
Backdrop
During the pandemic, auto sales fell off a cliff, but recovered swiftly. The most recent data shows, however, that car sales are slumping again. Why?
Sudden changes in auto sales can be demand or supply driven.
In normal circumstances, a sudden decline in auto sales leads to a corresponding increase in auto inventory
If the decline is supply driven, a decline in auto sales will be accompanied by a decline in inventories, as dealers sell of remaining stock to meet demand.
Let’s take a look at the data.



Predictably, during the pandemic, car sales dropped, accompanied by a spike in inventory. This suggests that the decline was demand-driven. More recently, however, the very low inventory suggests that car sales are supply-constrained.
Why Does It Matter?
Motor vehicle sales represent a sizable portion of consumer spending. At this stage it is not straightforward to assess how important supply constraints are in the overall economic picture, but from this data it is clear that supply bottlenecks are real.
Interestingly, while all automakers seem to suffer, a look at detailed data seems to suggest that notably light truck sales are driving the decline. Given the importance of trucks for U.S. car makers, they are among the hardest hit.

title: Post-Pandemic Expansion: How Is It Different?
description: Comparing The Current Recovery to Past Expansions
contents:
Backdrop
Every recession is different, but two exceptional ones were the 2008/09 financial crisis and the 2020 COVID pandemic. Both recessions were more severe than any other post-WW II recessions.
How does the post-recession recovery compare to history? To answer this, we index key economic indicators to their pre-recession peak, and trace their evolution through time.
Analysis
Let’s look at GDP first, the most comprehensive measure of economi activity. The chart below shows
the unprecedented depth of the economic contraction, and
the swift initial rebound, as economic activity restarted,
the slower expansion as the pandemic continued to linger



Why Does It Matter?
The panels below show the key GDP components. While private consumption is roughly on par with other recoveries, government spending seems a little slower. Overall, given the depths of the recession, the recovery is proceeding remarkably swift so far.

title: Welcome to Economic Tidbits: Why It Matters
description:
Economic Tidbits, or: Why It Matters. 

Background information on why we post what we post on https://twitter.com/EconomicsShiny
contents:
Economics is a complex topic, and everyone has their own favorite metric or indicator. In this blog we explain what we’re focused on, and why. Not saying that this is the only way to think about economics, or that this is the right way, but rather outlining why we look at what we’re looking at.
